turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Here, try this.  I suppose they're still making women the same as back then.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: It's beautiful.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: A little dusty.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I don't know any of these.  I'll make a fool of myself.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Follow me.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: William Taupin seems to have left his mark.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: And you are William Taupin, aren't you?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: You're using your son's name.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: No.  Just the child of some lonely girl I gave a ride to.  When they died I put them in a grave with my name on it. Twenty years later I became the son.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Then you must be at least 70 years old.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: At least.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: That's impossible.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: It's frightening sometimes the way you talk about other people's lives.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: A factor of age.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I hope I never get that old.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You won't.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I must be insane.  Leaving work, ditching cops.  All to follow a murderer.  A very old murderer, but a murderer just the same.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Why are you here?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I've been telling myself it's the award winning journal article I'm going to write.  But it's not.  It's you.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I'm not even sure why.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Hardly a reason to run off with a murderer.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: My life has been chock full of people with complications and weak- nesses.  I can't stand it.  But you're different.  It's in your hands.  A clarity.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You are a very perceptive young woman.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Just a little crazy.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: That would be difficult to explain.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I'd like you to try.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I carried that rifle in World War I.  This book is a 16th Century policy report for the King of Austria.  The diploma is my con- ference of degree in Latin from Trinity College.  Class of 1672.  It goes on.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: That's why Smith called you MacLeod.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: He knows about you.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: He is older than I.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What could possibly be worth all this murder and distruction.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Sometimes I think it's just for something to do.  A conquest to be the last.  Something to hold onto while everything else around you withers and blows away.  Some- thing to replace the love that can never work.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: That's insane.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Perhaps.  There is something more. An inheritance.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Of bodies.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I didn't kill the watchman.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: You killed those other two.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Not the same.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What about that family in '31?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Sometimes innocents become involved.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: You and your buddy make a real team, don't you?  Exchanging eloquent threats in iambic pen- tameter while hacking up all the innocents in between.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: There are differences.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: You kill with your left hand?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I haven't killed _you_.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Is that a threat?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Don't.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Come here, Brenna.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Damn you.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What is it like?  Being you?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Empty.  And fear.  Fear of those that would kill you and fear of those that would love you.  It can never last, and in the end you always end up destroying both.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: But you're known so much. History I'll only read about.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: It's all the same.  Half lives that never go away.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What is it you want?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: All of it finished.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Gettysburg's an hour's drive at most.  You should be back by nightfall.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Will I see you again?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Be careful.  Don't stay any longer than you have to.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I can't stand it.  Oh God, I can't stand it!

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I'm the last.  Oh Christ, I'm the _last one_!

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Get out.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I'll destroy you.  I've destroyed everything I've ever touched!  Oh God...

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: The emptyness.  The years and years of void.  Nothingness.  Bordered only by the quest for ultimate nothingness. Who would have guessed?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: The inheritance.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Not power.  Not control.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Life.  It is the gift and the under- standing of life.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: You have lived forever.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Life is only life when it is bounded by death.  The inheritance is death. The gift is the finality of life. To be part of the fabric.  The inside.  I love you Brenna.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: It will be horrible.  The future.  I may die tomorrow or 10,000 tomorrows. I can promise you nothing.  Nothing but a moment.  Maybe two.  But a moment of love, is that not worth a lifetime?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOE
turns.text: Forget it.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I'm just curious.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOE
turns.text: You're never "just curious".  You've met my neice, Brenna.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOE
turns.text: Aren't you getting a little old for this?  You flunked out of law school.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Now there's a new topic.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOE
turns.text: Don't they have enough for you to do at the castle?

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOE
turns.text: Forgers do it all the time.  They take the birth certificate of some- one who died young and use it to get legit I.D.  Usually they carry it long enough to pass some bad checks then dump it.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOE
turns.text: Call your mother.  You never call her.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: A murder.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: You better have a warrant.  That's my notebook, you've got no right to be sticking your fingers into it.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: I've got a morgue filling up with bodies.  That's my right.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What do you want from me?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Well, the man of the hour that we all would like to talk to about now has apparently skipped town.  And all of a sudden the Smithsonian's ambulence chaser is an expert on missing persons.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I'm calling an attorney.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: You and I should talk first.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: We've got nothing to say.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: What are you going to tell them?  That you're protecting a man who's killed four people?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Four?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: All fashionably without heads.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Spare me the details.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: But there's more.  Wednesday someone played javelin with the cemetary curator in Felton, Delaware.  Some locals spotted two cars with D.C. plates and surprise surprise, they turn out to be registered to our own Brenna Cartwright and the ever popular Richard Taupin.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What are you getting at, Moran?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: You've been a busy little beaver. Especially with that records mess up in Church Hill.  Your notes are very complete. Naturally my feelings were crushed when you didn't rush right over and tell us what you knew.  In fact, we're considering book- ing the ambulence chaser as an accessory to murder.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: It'll never stick.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: But we might just give it the 'ole college try.  What with the court back ups, it could be days before you got an arraignment. But then, I'm sure the flunk-out neice of the D.A. knows all about that.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: You're an asshole, Moran.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: I want Taupin.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What makes you so sure he's the one?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Just for laughs we raided wonder boy's house.  There was a gallon of one of the corpse's blood in his carpet.  I think it was about then I withdrew his name for humanitarian of the year.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What's all of this got to do with me?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: What were you doing in Felton?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Research.  If your pal was there I never saw him.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: I have witnesses that can put the two of you together.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Never take up poker, Detective.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Don't be stupid, lady.  Your neck can be sliced as fast as anyone else's.

turns.speaker: LIBRARIAN
turns.text: Come on Brenna, your ass is already in a sling, don't drag me into it.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: All I need is for you to check the name.

turns.speaker: LIBRARIAN
turns.text: You talked to your supervisor lately?  He's burning up the place about you just dropping out of sight.  That on top of the cops bugging him.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I'll take care of that Corey, but I need this now.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Corey, you _owe_ me.

turns.speaker: LIBRARIAN
turns.text: It's that important?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LIBRARIAN
turns.text: Good way to lose your job.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Some job.  Card filing and cabinet dusting.  Four years in this dump and I haven't written anything for Wilson that a wounded yak couldn't do.

turns.speaker: LIBRARIAN
turns.text: I liked the bit you did about Baltic chastity belts. Too bad no one else did.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: It's bullshit.  Everything. My job, the people I get involved with, I'm up to here with it.

turns.speaker: LIBRARIAN
turns.text: You always were hard to impress.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: LIBRARIAN
turns.text: Not who.  What.  Worstick's a town in Pennsylvania.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I don't believe him.

turns.speaker: SUPERVISOR
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: He's too cool.  Too sharp.  I think he's got something to do with it.

turns.speaker: SUPERVISOR
turns.text: Hang on a sec, you did your little favor for the boys downtown, I'm sure your uncle and the rest are perfectly capable of taking it from here.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I've seen nobleman swords that weren't as well preserved.  It's just a hunk of peasant iron.  Why would he be carrying it around in an alley?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Someone should check him out. Maybe a collection somewhere got knocked over.  He has one, he might have two.

turns.speaker: SUPERVISOR
turns.text: You see that desk?  _Your_ desk?  You see the crap piled up on it?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Give it a rest Ned, huh?

turns.speaker: TAVERN MAN #2
turns.text: Requiem acer'nam donaei-

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: What are you doing man?

turns.speaker: TAVERN MAN #2
turns.text: -Et lux perpetua-

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: You'll not be bringing the church into this.

turns.speaker: TAVERN MAN #2
turns.text: -Luceat ei-

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Be quiet.

turns.speaker: TAVERN MAN #2
turns.text: -Auditorium nostrum-

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Stop.

turns.speaker: TAVERN MAN #2
turns.text: -In nomine sanctus esperitu-

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Stop!

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Afternoon.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Your name is Conor?

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Aye.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Juan Cid Romirez.  Chief surveyor and alchemist.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: You're not from these parts.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: I am from Spain.  And I would like a moment of your time.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I haven't much to offer, Mr. Romirez from Spain, but you're welcome to what's here.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Please go to no trouble.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Your back, it would seem perhaps you were injured in battle?

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Five years past me clan fought another over some- thing I cannot even re- member.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Your marks would suggest great injury.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I was nearly killed.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: But you lived.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I did at that.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: And but for a mark you are well as any man, no?

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Aye.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: I should imagine that your recovery must have alarmed your fellow villagers, perhaps giving them reason to invent an explanation.  And a solution.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I was driven out.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: And now you live in a small village miles away from all you knew.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: How can you know this?

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: First food, no?  A good meal makes conversation so much easier.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Hmm, que rico.  What is it you call this?

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Pheasant.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: You Scots have a way with game.  It still has life in it. Spirit.  Back home the food is so...domestic.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Why are you here?

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: I was sent by his majesty of Spain to Inverness as a con- sultant on matters of metal.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: You're a long way from Inverness.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: In my travels I heard the story of the MacLeod boy struck down and brought from the hand of death by powers not of this Earth.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: You know me home.  Me name.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: It was time for our paths to cross.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: When I was a boy a cart driven by a drunken fool crushed me.  All thought I would die or be maimed for life.  But I healed quickly. And like you I paid the price for being different.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: You are the same?

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Do you ever feel a flow, as if some- thing were pushing against you?

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Yes.  Always.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Does it change with me in the room?

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: It is less.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: You feel you know me.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I don't know why.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: We are brothers.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: He told me there could be only one.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Some cling to sanity through time with the one continuity and trad0 ition their lives have known: The Game.  You and I Conor, we are different from all others around us.  You know this, you can feel it.  We are flesh and bone like any man, but unlike our neighbors we are rather difficult to injure,  permanently.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: You are still so very young.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I'm twenty-two.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Not even a single lifetime.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Conor, you and I, we cannot be killed.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: We are immortal.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: It is as you are.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Listen to me.  Hear the words.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: This is madness!

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: It is the truth.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Three days you've laid there. It's time you ate.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: This can't be.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: You are not dead, boy.  Accept it.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: This is monstrous.  I'll burn in hell for all eternity.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: You'd have to die first.  Aqui.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: What is to become of me?  Am I to wander the Earth forever like a ghost?

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: You will live.  Survive.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Then they were right.  I am evil. This is God's punishment.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: You have done nothing wrong Conor MacLeod.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Oh my God.  Oh my God I'm lost.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Why does he want to kill me?

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: You recall how I spoke of the push you feel and how I make it less?

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Aye.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: It is always less with my living. Far or near.  But if I were to die the push would become stronger than ever before.  There is power in this.  And as long as you and I live, The Knight can never have it all.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: But we cannot be killed.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: There is an imperfection.  For all your healing, if your head ever leaves your neck, you are dead. You can survive anything but steel against your threat.  Then it is over.  The end.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: How can I stop such a man?

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Hide.  Run to the ends of the Earth till you learn.  You must learn to defend yourself.  In this I can help.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: We are brothers.  And you are a defense-  -of sorts.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Harder.  Concentrate harder.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Me arm hurts.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Again.  Try again.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Harder!  You swing like an impotent cow!

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Go to hell.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Oh, the boy has a mouth, now if only he had an arm.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Impotent cow.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Muy Bien!

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: It will take less effort as you learn.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: It's like to kill me first.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: You have a gift.  One you must protect.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: And what is this great gift that cannot be seen or smelt?

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: The Fabric of life.  The spark that allows the passing of existence from one generation to another.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: If that was meant to be an ex- planation Mr. Romirez from Spain, I'm afraid you've failed.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: You're no match for Scot, Mr. Romirez.  We're raised as riders.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Point conceeded, Mr. MacLeod.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: What is the fascinatioon?  It is only a leaf.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: All living things pay dues, Conor.  They must be respected for that.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: As they age they contribute to a sum that is the kindling from which all future life comes.  To feel it, to know it, is to be in touch with the will of every living thing.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I do not think I like the sound of that.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: It does not feel nearly as frightening as it sounds.  But the consequences of such feelings can be very frightening. For it gives you great strength.  The strength of _knowledge_.  The ability to stand between the giving of what has always been to what will always be.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I feel hardly nothing.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: You have not been fully trained. But you will learn.  And you will be good, I can feel that.  You have apt- itude.  This is why our friend is so concerned.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: But why be so concerned about me?

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: This power is divided amongst you, me, and others like cuts in a pie. But the cuts are not equal.  Some, like you and he, have more.  Much more.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: And you?

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: I am a small player.  But if by helping you I can keep that monster from being the last, then perhaps my life has meant something.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I am not ready for this.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: You must be.  You have responsibilities. You must learn the rules.  You can never attract attention to yourself, never show the side that will draw others to you.  You will always know when you are in the presence of another.  Beware. But more importantly Conor MacLeod, will be your battle against time.  In the coming years you will see kingdoms rise then rot like wheat.  People will become a transitory, pathetic lot.  The only constant you will know will be the others and the tradition their greed and quest represent.  But life without morality, without the ability to truly taste the sweetness of wine and love, is no life at all.  That is how the others exist.  Nothing more than walking corpses living only to slaughter each other in an insane quest to be the last.  Keep your soul sewed to the earth.  Do not become one of them.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: You are young, inexperienced.  You do not know what time can do.  How it can sap all pity, all love.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: That is not me.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: With the proper tools, Conor, a naive man can be much more dangerous than an evil one.

turns.speaker: ROMIREZ
turns.text: Go ahead, Senor.  I have my friend to keep me company.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I'll be back when I can.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I'm your future husband, remember?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: I have no future husband.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I don't understand.  Not a week ago your father gave us his blessing.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: My future husband died in battle against the Sutherlands.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: What are you saying?  I'm standing here as real as you.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: You cannot be real, Conor.  You had the last rites.  No man has been cut half as bad and lived.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: But I did live.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Live?  In less than a week you're prancing about the country like a squirrel.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: So why the crazy talk?  It's a miracle it is.  Saint Andrew has smiled on me.  On us.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Some think not.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: There's rumor in the village. Some call it magic.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: That's mad.  Surely you don't take their word?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: I don't know, Conor.  It's not natural.  Maybe something has touched you.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: You're sounding like that mad woman, Widow Baggins.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Me father has taken back my hand.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Please not be touching me, Conor.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: I'll not take that kind of talk from you.  From those others below, maybe.  But not from you.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Leave me alone, Conor.  Please.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: You're not talking sense, Mara!

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: If you send me away now, Mara, I'll not come looking for you.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Do what you must.

turns.speaker: KATHERINE
turns.text: Oh please.  Another one.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: What would you like?

turns.speaker: KATHERINE
turns.text: Something pretty.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Like you.

turns.speaker: KATHERINE
turns.text: That's wonderful.  Where did you ever learn it?

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Far away.

turns.speaker: KATHERINE
turns.text: Kiss me.

turns.speaker: KATHERINE
turns.text: David.

turns.speaker: CONOR
turns.text: Do you have cause to bothering us?

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Who am I deceiving?

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: Certainly not me.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: State of grace and all that.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Tradition.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: It's all we have.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Not so scared.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: Perhaps not.  You seem to have misplaced a private.  No doubt by now his head is stranger to his neck.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: No doubt.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: You surprise me.  Eliminating a rival like that.  Such are the actions of a man of conquest.  I was mistaken.  300 years have turned the boy's fear into ambit- ion.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: You're wrong.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: I know you very well, Conor MacLeod. And I can see the truth beginning to make itself clear to you.  Mulet, Romirez, they were fools without vision.  It was destined that the board would be cleared for the real players.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Romirez understood.  Not you.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: Romirez is dust.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: Finish your prayers?

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Finish yours?

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: Our common heritage.  I am your only real friend, you know.  The only one who truly understands you.  I look forward to the day we meet again.  And I kill you.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: So sure?

turns.speaker: MAJOR
turns.text: Complete your inspection?

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: They're nothing but boys.  It will be a slaughter tomorrow.

turns.speaker: MAJOR
turns.text: I doubt much can change that. The enemy has five brigades waiting for us.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: We need more time.

turns.speaker: MAJOR
turns.text: Won't get it.  We are a sacrifice.  A diversion.

turns.speaker: MAJOR
turns.text: Eat up Dupont.  It will probably be your last.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Not likely.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Your name?

turns.speaker: MULET
turns.text: Mulet.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: I thought I gave orders the regiment was to drill.

turns.speaker: MULET
turns.text: Staff sargeant detailed me to prepare firewood for the break- fast cooking.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: What is your position?

turns.speaker: MULET
turns.text: Second musketeer.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: I understand you joined up in Bremen.

turns.speaker: MULET
turns.text: You seem to understand a great deal.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: I am a Major, Private.  You would do well remembering that when addressing me.

turns.speaker: MULET
turns.text: Excuse me, "sir".  I thought we spoke as equals.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Equals?

turns.speaker: MULET
turns.text: If you wish to play games, Major.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Wait.  I think we understand each other.

turns.speaker: MULET
turns.text: We have no understanding.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Then it is time two of us did. You are very young.  I was once young.  I can help.

turns.speaker: MULET
turns.text: Help?  I've seen others "help". Somehow a head always ended up on the counter.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: It can be different.  It must be.

turns.speaker: MULET
turns.text: It never changes, Major.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: We must talk.

turns.speaker: MULET
turns.text: Stay out of it.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Don't threaten me, Private.

turns.speaker: MULET
turns.text: Who do you think I am?  One of your freckle faced children waiting to die tomorrow?  "Threaten you"?  You and I just living will always be a threat.  Forever.  Look at your life, Major.  Look at mine.  Nothing there but threat.  Threats and nothingness. It's what we live for.

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Do not turn your back on me.

turns.speaker: MULET
turns.text: You are really going to force this, aren't you?

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: Either you are with me or against me.

turns.speaker: MULET
turns.text: You see Major?  You are not so different...

turns.speaker: DUPONT
turns.text: I had no choice.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: Ah, Conor, how you look a man.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Have you time for some- thing to eat?

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: Your grandfather wore that in his service to the King, and I to fight for the Duke.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Must he go?

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: Aye.  It is his duty.  All of ours.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: But Ian, he's still but a boy.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: He's a MacLeod.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Here.  The hook should go just below the head, where the meat is toughest.

turns.speaker: GRANDSON
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Fish are creatures of habit.  They like their food where they're used to it.  At the top, hiding in old leaves.

turns.speaker: GRANDSON
turns.text: Where did you learn that?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: My father taught me.

turns.speaker: GRANDSON
turns.text: Your father must be smart.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Yes, he was.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: I want people in here to check over every piece of this stuff.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Figure she's with him?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: We ran down that Church Hill info. She's right.  There is no Richard Taupin.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Any other I.D.s come up?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Not yet.  Called FBI yesterday. Thompson's going to try CIA this afternoon.  Y'never know.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Should have seen him the first night.  Son of a bitch stood there with a quart of blood on his pant leg and didn't even blink.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: You'd think he'd had practice.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Won't know till the records department comes back with it this after- noon.  Looks good though. They found the receipt in his townhouse.  It was pretty smeared but had Taupin's father listed as a signatory.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Round up who you can and put them on standby.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Think we should call the local P.D. out there first?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: No.  I want this to be all ours.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Where!

turns.speaker: INTRUDER
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: What name is he using?

turns.speaker: INTRUDER
turns.text: Smith.  Carl Smith.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: How many came?

turns.speaker: INTRUDER
turns.text: The last four.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: And the Bulgarian?

turns.speaker: INTRUDER
turns.text: He got him.  He always does.  Eventually.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: He knows I'm here.  How?

turns.speaker: INTRUDER
turns.text: None of this would be happening if you hadn't run...

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: _Answer_ me.

turns.speaker: INTRUDER
turns.text: We learned he'd found the immigration notaries in Liverpool and traced them to New York.  Then he figured out the birth records in Church Hill...

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: Spare a chair?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Kahn?

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: Are you going to offer me a chair or leave me standing here all night?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Sit.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: How are you?

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: Head still secure to the neck.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: How did you find me?

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: How many places this side of the Atlantic serve lager and lime?

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: Old habits die hard.  Waitress!  A round of Nitzhic!  Peasant drool, I know.  But it's the closest thing they stock to my side of the fence.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: It is the gathering, my friend.  The settling of old scores.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: And have you something to settle with me?

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: Not tonight.  Tonight I have a drink with an old friend.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: It's good to see you, Kahn.

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: I'll never forget the look on that Papal commander's face when his "heretic stronghold" turned out to be a rock full of whores climbing all over Neuvich.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Neuvich, the clown of the crusades.

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: But then rides up Pope Pius who calmly brushes the dust from his papal cross, climbs off his papal horse, draws his papal sword and asks just what the hell is going on.  And what did Neuvich, dear dear drunken Neuvich do?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Offered the Pope one of his whores.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Had a great swing with his blade. For a Pope.

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: Good times then.  A man could stretch his legs without bring- ing half the world down around his ears.  Not like now.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: He found us even there.

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: He always did.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I haven't drunk this much since-

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: -Since you last saw me.

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: I love zoos.  Ever since I was a kid.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You were never a kid.

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: I knew his great-grandfather.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You're insane.

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: No, seriously.  We used to shoot pool together in Rangoon.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: How do you do it, Kahn?  How do you live so full of life for so long?

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: Tasting and enjoying life is the only thing of value we have.  All else is just marking time.  You're marking time.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I've had a few more concerns.

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: The pressure only comes when you let the taste slip into your mouth.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You're wrong.

turns.speaker: KAHN
turns.text: You don't run as hard, MacLeod. You just don't run as hard anymore.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: Long time.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Not so long.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You've been here from the start.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: My quarry grows clever with age.  And the others, incompetent.
